question: Okay. For Christsakes!
answer: It's a flood, Charlie. You're gonna get wet.

question: Hey! Do you know what kind of crap is in that water?
answer: Well, yeah.

question: Dispatch, this is 31. We're leaving Huntingburg. We'll be back in an hour. We're gone. Over and out. What?
answer: Your ear.

question: What about my ear?
answer: You've got a major hair growth going on.

question: Shut up.
answer: I'm serious. You're gonna need somebody to go in there with a weed whacker.

question: Here.
answer: You're offering me one of your donuts? I don't know what to say. I'm getting all misty.

question: If it'll shut your mouth you can have the whole bag.
answer: Nah. I start eating donuts and I'll never get out of this truck.

question: I love how you think you're better than this.
answer: Don't get me wrong, Charlie. There's a lot to like about this job -- and I don't just mean the dashing polyester ensemble and the solid three-figure income.

question: You ungrateful shit! I don't believe you!
answer: Charlie, relax! I was kidding!

question: You don't wanna do this? Fine. Go back to selling hot construction machinery. That's a helluva career.
answer: It had better hours.

question: You think this is a joke? This is funny? Jesus Christ! You know how lucky you are you could get in here? Thirty years old and all the crap you pulled and you never got caught?
answer: That wasn't luck, old man. That was skill. I was good at it.

question: Oh, yeah, it takes a lot of skill to fence bulldozers. That's goddamn genius time.
answer: About as much skill as it takes to sit in a truck and get fat eating donuts.

question: Oh, so that's all I've been doing, huh? Just wasting my life away.
answer: I didn't say that.

question: Yeah, building a home, raising a family -- that's just stupid.
answer: I didn't say that!

question: "Thus saith the Lord; Behold, waters shall rise up out of the north and be an overflowing flood and all the inhabitants of the land shall howl." Jeremiah 47:2.
answer: You're gonna be able to buy a helluva lot of bibles, huh, Ray? Me? First thing I'm gonna do is get my brother a lawyer. Best that money can buy.

question: What's he facing?
answer: Thirty in.

question: He cap a cop or something...?
answer: Security guard. "In the commission..." All he's got is a piece of shit P.D. Now I'm gonna be able to afford him a good lawyer -- a guy with a haircut.

question: Jerk.
answer: Jack-ass.

question: Give us a kiss. Come on.
answer: Get out of here.

question: You really are a cranky old fart, you know that?
answer: I'm sorry.

question: What was that about? I mean, I'm just sitting here and all of a sudden you go postal on me.
answer: I don't know, I... It's just this weather. I... I want to get back.

question: You know, I really do appreciate what you've done for me. This is a good job.
answer: No, it's not. It stinks. It's putting your life on the line for someone else's money.

question: I just think, whatever it is you do, it's time you did some heavy lifting.
answer: Stop!

question: No, you gotta hear this. You're better than --
answer: Stop the truck! We're going down!

question: Back up!
answer: Goddammit!

question: It's a little dip in the road or something. You can see the reflectors come up the other side.
answer: I knew this would happen.

question: I'll see if there's anyone coming. Maybe we can get pulled out.
answer: Dispatch, this is 31. 31 calling dispatch. Dispatch, we're stuck outside of Huntingburg. Truck's dead. We're on 231, headed for the Interstate. Right by a sign saying "Welcome to Huntingburg."

question: The town's been evacuated. We won't get any help from there.
answer: Dispatch can't get anyone out.

question: They are aware we're carrying a shitload of money...?
answer: They called the National Guard. They're gonna be here in about ninety minutes.

question: Ninety minutes? Jesus.
answer: Dispatch, we're gonna need help a little sooner than --

question: You don't need to set traps.
answer: That's what they said in '73. When we got back, anything the bastards didn't steal they broke, just for the hell of it.

question: That's not happening this time.
answer: Damn right it's not.

question: There's always that. Either way, we got ourselves a sharp one.
answer: What do we do?

question: Pretty soon the water'll be too deep for him to run. But for us it'll be just deep enough.
answer: Deep enough for what?

question: Here we go.
answer: What about this monster?

question: Surfaces, gasping.
answer: Hears the gasp, turns, grinning. Enemy sub off the port bow!

question: Gets to his feet runs as fast as he can down the hall. He rounds a corner and keeps going.
answer: Guns his engine and takes off after Tom.

question: Runs another thirty feet, then trips on something and goes down.
answer: Comes around the corner, grinning when he sees...

question: Halfway down the hall, standing frozen, caught in Kenny's light.
answer: Guns it, racing forward down the hall toward Tom. Full steam ahead! Keeps going. He flies through the air, slams headfirst into a trophy case and drops into the water.

question: Did you see the stained glass windows, Phil? Did you see what a good job they did? I can't let anything happen to the church, not after all I've put into it.
answer: Karen, you know I'd do anything for you, but the Sheriff told me to get you out of town. I'm sorry. It's for your own good. What're you doing?

question: If you're not going to take me back to the church, then I'll swim.
answer: No. Hey, hold on.

question: Tom hears the sound and opens his eyes -- what the hell is that?
answer: The wall of water slams in hard, cascading over the sandbag wall.

question: TOM SITS UP, SWINGING HIS LEGS OVER THE SIDE OF THE COT. HE REACTS, LOOKS DOWN. HIS POV
answer: The building is like a rock in a stream, with the water rushing up high against one wall, roiling and swirling around the sides.

question: Tries the keys in the lock. They don't fit. He looks at them. Great! I can drive out of here! Climbs up the cell bars, the water rising with him. He's running out of room between himself and the ceiling. Three feet. Two feet. He's being pushed up by the water toward... Is terrified, about to die. The water rises up past his face. Sticks the flashlight tube up through the wire grate over the light fixture. Looks up, astonished, to see...
answer: And she's pulling as hard as she can, but the wire cage isn't budging. She pulls out a Swiss Army knife, unfolds a small knife and starts taking out the screws holding the cage in place. She gets two screws out.

question: Pulls on the cage and it swings down. He climbs up it. Thank you.
answer: I owed you -- for hitting you and all. But we're even now, okay?

question: Even. What happened?
answer: I don't know. Maybe another levee broke upriver. They've been --

question: So what do we do?
answer: I guess just drive around until we run out of gas.

question: Look, I've spent the last eight months of my life restoring that church, and I just left it to come save your ass, so spare me, okay?
answer: When we get down here a little further we'll find a place for you to hide. I'm gonna get back to the truck and wait for the National Guard. They should be there pretty soon. Cold?

question: You ever been robbed before?
answer: No. The scariest thing that ever happened before was Charlie running out of donuts. I've only been doing this for a couple months.

question: Oh. What'd you do before this?
answer: I, uh... I sold construction machinery. I was making good money, it just... I don't know. It just didn't seem right for me anymore.

question: How'd you end up in this?
answer: My uncle did me a favor; got me in.

question: Nice favor. How's he gonna feel after tonight?
answer: My uncle was Charlie -- my partner in the truck.

question: Jesus, I can't stop shivering. I know you didn't want me to come.
answer: You kidding? We couldn't've done anything without you.

question: My dad'd sure be pissed off, huh?
answer: Your dad'd just want you to lay still while we got you some help.

question: Hey -- hey the pain's goin'. Oh, man. When you said I was gonna be okay, I thought you were just shittin' me.
answer: See? You gotta trust me.

question: You can't swim that far in fifteen minutes.
answer: He could take our boat.

question: Henry!
answer: I'll go get it ready for you.

question: Kicks away, horrified. And then he hears an engine. He looks.
answer: Son, before you go underwater and do something tricky, there's something I'd like you to see!

question: Slumps.
answer: Now, I know it's your job to protect that money, and maybe you'd even be foolish enough to give your life for it. The question is, are you willing to give their lives for it? Drop the gun and get into the boat.

question: Thinks for a second, then throws the shotgun away and pulls himself into the rowboat.
answer: Excellent choice.

question: In the attic. They never saw her.
answer: Faster, Henry! The bastards might change their minds! Stop lily- dipping and move it! What're you doing?

question: I'm gonna row back there and see if he'll shoot you. Or me. Fine either way.
answer: Henry...?

question: Do you want me to get us out of here?
answer: Yes, of course, I --

question: Here?
answer: Uh... no. A little farther --

question: They're not coming, son.
answer: What?

question: The National Guard. They're not coming.
answer: I don't --

question: I know you've been trying to stall until they show up, but they're not coming.
answer: Oh, God. You intercepted Charlie's call, then you called them off.

question: We were gonna hit you just before you got on the Interstate, but then you got stuck so we had to change our plans and take you --
answer: Bullshit. This is all bullshit.

question: I knew Charlie when we were both working construction for the Johnstown company. His middle name was McCarthy because his parents loved Charlie McCarthy on the radio. His wife's name was Mary. She died of a heart- attack last year. He has a daughter and a son, both grown with children of their own. I'm afraid I don't know the names of the grandchildren. What else do I know...? Oh, yes. I know Uncle Charlie was trying to steer his favorite nephew away from a life of crime.
answer: Why'd you shoot him? Kill Charlie and you get to keep another share?

question: I'm gonna ask you one more time. And before you think of bullshitting me again, keep in mind I have had a very frustrating night. And while I know I'll never get the money if I kill you, it's getting to the point where I just don't care.
answer: I'll tell you where it is. But it's not going to do you any good. The Guard may not be coming, but someone else sure as hell is.

question: I'll take my chances.
answer: There.

question: Then I guess you've never been hunting with Hank. We got two behind that crypt. Get 'em.
answer: Maybe I'm not okay with it.

question: Come on now, Phil.
answer: You're gonna kill people?

question: They're looters, Phil! They come and steal from an armored truck in our town -- they're looters.
answer: What about Tom? What about Karen? They're not looters.

question: Gets to Jim's boat and grabs onto it.
answer: Cranks the throttle, and, dragging Tom, tears off under the hail of Wayne's bullets.

question: Rams into one cross.
answer: Grabs Tom's hand and holds on as they shoot off across the water.

question: You really want that money? 'Cause the only way you're ever gonna see it is if you help me get Karen. We're too slow.
answer: Here.

question: Then go get some bottles.
answer: Wait -- what about the dam?

question: It'll be fine.
answer: You said if it goes it'll wipe out the town.

question: Does he have the girl?
answer: She's in the small boat. Jesus, I'm gonna get hepatitis.

question: Hepatitis, hell. You probably already got cholera. What're you doing?
answer: There's a back room. Maybe they've got something I can use on this.

question: You been in here before?
answer: Oh, yeah.

question: What happened?
answer: I saw Jesus.

question: Enters from the back. He's got a bottle of rubbing alcohol and a towel. He splashes some of the alcohol on the towel, then touches it to his wound. It hurts like a sonofabitch. After a beat... So, has this all gone pretty much how you thought it would?
answer: Everything would have gone fine if you'd've just walked away from the truck.

question: Oh, yeah? Well, everything would've gone even better if you hadn't decided to rob the damn truck in the first place! Did Charlie have cancer or something?
answer: You mean why was he doing this? No cancer. Didn't you ever think about taking the money?

question: No.
answer: Come now. A man who used to make his living fencing hot jackhammers never thought about what he'd do with three million dollars?

question: Sorry to disappoint you. What are you gonna do with it?
answer: As little as possible.

question: Belize. It's this small country in Central America, on the Atlantic side.
answer: I know where Belize is. What about it?

question: They speak English and the dollar goes a long way. Beautiful beaches; friendly people. And they've got liberal banking laws. Very liberal.
answer: No, you didn't think about taking that money at all.

question: You can't ride in the truck and not think about it.
answer: I'm sure. And I guess that's pretty much how it started with Charlie.

question: Where's Wayne going?
answer: On a date. You all set?

question: Yeah, but --
answer: Then let's go.

question: Aren't we gonna wait for Wayne?
answer: We can get started without him, the dumb shit. He won't be long. Besides, we got Phil. Phil's gonna earn his money on this, aren't you Phil?

question: What -- you're gonna swim after her? You ain't gonna help her by getting shot. He's gone and you don't know where.
answer: The Sheriff knows. I think maybe I'll go ask him.

question: You'll be dead before you get over the sandbags. Look, he'll be coming for us. You can ask him then.
answer: What if he doesn't come?

question: Wakey-wakey. Dear Penthouse And she said...
answer: Sorry, Wayne, but I'm not playing a part in your sick little play.

question: You're perfect for the role. I suggest you reconsider.
answer: Or what? You'll kill me? You're gonna do that anyway.

question: I might get clumsy. It might take a while.
answer: I'm sure you can hurt me. But it's all going to be the same when I'm dead.

question: And she said, "Happy Birthday, Wayne. I've got something for you." Well, I'm not stupid. I knew what she wanted to give me and I knew she wanted to give it bad, so I -- That won't do. Man's gotta see what he's doing. 'Scuse me.
answer: Raises her hips and digs a hand into her pocket and pulls out her Swiss Army knife. She pries open the big blade. She hears Wayne sloshing back toward her. She gets back into the position Wayne left her in as...

question: Re-enters carrying two burning candles in candle-holders. I got the candles. All's we need is a cake. Mood lighting. You in the mood yet? And then she said, "My present's ready and waiting. All's you gotta do is unwrap it." It was cold and rainy that birthday night, and all I wanted was to get someplace warm and dry. As it turned out, what I really wanted was something warm and wet. Wayne grins and closes for a kiss and... His head jerks back. He tries to shout, but all that comes out is an awful gurgle. He tries to push off Karen, but...
answer: Wraps her legs around him, holds him close, pinning him.

question: Finally breaks free. He tries to stop the bleeding with a hand, but the blood spurts through his fingers. He reaches for his gun in his holster on the banister, but just as he grabs it...
answer: Lashes out of the water with her legs, kicking Wayne in the groin, pushing him back.

question: Tries to get his balance, but his feet can't move -- his pants are around his ankles. He falls back into the water, firing his pistol. Is floating on his back, trying to lift the pistol, but his strength is fading fast. He gets off one last shot and... The gun drops into the water. No more shots. No more life. He floats, pants around his ankles, covered in blood, dead.
answer: Happy Birthday, Wayne.

question: There have to be keys. There --
answer: Still floating on his back, still dead. She looks closer at...

question: Reaches out with her foot for Wayne's pants. She can't reach.
answer: Is slowly drifting out the open door. Beyond the door, in the light of the streetlamp, the water is riffling, moving, and Wayne is heading toward it.

question: Slides down further on the stairs, into the water, then stops. Reaches out with a foot, straining, stretching her body, almost dislocating her shoulder and... Can only watch as...
answer: Drifts out the door and is pulled away by the current.

question: Is caught between Hank's bullets and the Sheriff's bullets. So he racks a load in the shotgun and dives backwards off the balcony.
answer: Is still shooting up as...

question: Arcs off the balcony, firing the shotgun under the balcony at Hank.
answer: Dives to the floor of his boat as Tom's shotgun blasts blow plate-sized holes in the church doors.

question: Lands in the water and goes under.
answer: Starts to get up from the bottom of his boat, searching for a clip for his gun.

question: Draws a bead on Jim and is about to shoot when...
answer: Comes out of the water on the other side of Hank's boat. Tom pushes down hard on the side of the boat.

question: Is rocked back, thrown off balance. He starts to spin and bring his gun around when...
answer: Swings with the shotgun, catching...

question: Hank?
answer: It's topped out.

question: How much time we got?
answer: How should I know?

question: Guess!
answer: It's an old dam! Not long.

question: Wades in along the upper hall. I'm guessing you can't get up.
answer: I'm handcuffed. The railing's bolted to the wall. I've got a saw.

question: Where?
answer: In the kitchen. In the tall cupboard beside the --

question: With Jim at the wheel, comes racing straight toward the house.
answer: Thinks he's going to turn. No! No!

question: Doesn't turn.
answer: Rolls to the side, just getting clear as...

question: Tries to restart the ski-boat but it's dead. He slumps forward.
answer: Sees Jim slump against the side of the boat. You okay?

question: Fine.
answer: Oh, God. We gotta get you to -- Thanks.

question: For what?
answer: You just saved our lives.

question: No. Tell her to stay back.
answer: It's okay!

question: You're going to turn it in?
answer: Sorry to disappoint you.

question: Well, hell, then I guess I better take it after all. I figure the river'll carry me down to the Gulf of Mexico. If I catch the right currents, maybe I'll end up in... Belize? You come look me up. I'll buy you a drink.
answer: I'll do that.

question: Go. Please. Son, don't think too badly of your Uncle Charlie. He always said you were capable of remarkable things. He was right. The rain's stopped. The air after a rain...
answer: Swims through the swirling current toward Karen's roof.
